defend.translation[0].definitions[0].def: to do something in order to protect someone or something from being attacked
defend.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: a struggle to defend our homeland
the need to defend democracy against fascism
advice on how women can defend themselves from sex attackers
We need to defend against military aggression.
defend.translation[0].definitions[1].def: to use arguments to protect something or someone from criticism, or to prove that something is right
defend.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: She was always defending her husband in front of their daughter.
Students should be ready to explain and defend their views.
Cooper wrote to the journal immediately, defending himself.
He defended his wife against rumours and allegations.
defend.translation[0].definitions[1].not: In everyday English, people usually say stand up for someone rather than defend someone:
She was the only person who stood up for me at the meeting.
defend.translation[0].definitions[2].def: to do something in order to stop something from being taken away or in order to make it possible for something to continue
defend.translation[0].definitions[2].exa: the workers’ attempts to defend their interests
We are defending the right to demonstrate.
defend.translation[0].definitions[3].def: to protect your own team’s end of the field in a game such as football, in order to prevent your opponents from getting points
defend.translation[0].definitions[3].exa: Bournemouth defended well throughout the game.
defend.translation[0].definitions[4].def: to take part in a competition that you won the last time it was held, and try to win it again
defend.translation[0].definitions[4].exa: The world champion was defending his title.
He is defending a Labour majority of 5,000.
defend.translation[0].definitions[5].def: to be a lawyer for someone who has been charged with a crime
defend.translation[0].definitions[5].exa: He had top lawyers to defend him.
Howard, defending, said Thompson had been drinking heavily.
defend.translation[0].note_box[0].sectio: to say something to support an idea or person when other people are criticizing them
The mayor defended the action, saying that it was the best option.
to strongly defend someone who is being criticized, or strongly defend your ideas or your rights
My grandfather would always stand up for what was right.
I don't want him fighting, but I do want him to stand up for himself.
to strongly defend someone who is being criticized, especially when no one else will defend them
The other kids tease her, but Sarah often sticks up for her.
to say something to defend someone who is being criticized
Aitken's colleagues quickly came to his defence.
defend.translation[1].definitions[0].def: if a lawyer defends someone charged with a crime, he or she represents that person and argues that they are not guilty of the charge
defend.translation[1].definitions[1].def: to do something in order to stop something being taken away or to make sure that something continues
defend.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: The union said that they would take strike action to defend their members’ jobs.
